messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

user.py: def __init__(self, email, password, profile_picture=None, status_message=None, privacy_setting='public'):
return 'Password recovery link sent to ' + email
test_user.py: assert user_db.password_recovery('test@test.com') == 'Password recovery link sent to test@test.com'

steps: Step 1: User Registration and Authentication: Start by creating a User class with attributes such as email, password, and other necessary details. Implement methods for user registration (sign up) and password recovery. The sign-up method should take in an email and password, and add a new user to the in-memory database (mocked as a dictionary). The password recovery method should simulate the process of sending a password recovery link to the user's email. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that a user can be successfully registered and that the password recovery process works as expected.

Step 2: User Profile: Extend the User class to include profile-related attributes such as profile picture and status message. Implement methods to set these attributes. Also, add a privacy setting attribute that determines who can see the user's details or last seen status. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that the user's profile can be successfully updated and that the privacy settings work as expected.

Step 3: Contact Management: Create a Contact class with attributes such as contact name and blocked status. Implement methods to block and unblock contacts. Also, create a Group class with attributes such as group name and list of members. Implement methods to create, edit, and manage groups. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that contacts can be successfully blocked/unblocked and that groups can be successfully created, edited, and managed.

Step 4: Messaging: Create a Message class with attributes such as sender, receiver, content, read receipt status, and encryption status. Implement methods to send and receive messages, update read receipt status, and encrypt/decrypt messages. Also, extend the Message class to support image sharing and emojis, GIFs, and stickers. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that messages can be successfully sent and received, that read receipts are updated correctly, and that encryption works as expected.

Step 5: Group Chats: Extend the Group class to include a group chat attribute, which is a list of Messages. Implement methods to add or remove participants and to assign admin roles and permissions. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that group chats function correctly, that participants can be added or removed, and that admin roles and permissions are assigned correctly.

Step 6: Status/Story Feature: Extend the User class to include a status attribute, which is a list of Status objects. A Status object has attributes such as content (image), visibility duration, and visibility settings. Implement methods to post a new status and to control who can see the status. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that statuses can be successfully posted and that the visibility settings work as expected.

Step 7: Web Application: Create a Flask application that provides a web interface for the chat service. Implement routes for user registration, login, profile management, contact management, messaging, group chats, and status posting. After implementing these routes, write tests to ensure that the web application works as expected.

Step 8: Connectivity and Offline Mode: Implement a feature that queues messages when the user is offline and sends them once connectivity is restored. Also, add an online/offline status attribute to the User class and implement methods to update and display this status. After implementing these features, write tests to ensure that the message queuing and online/offline status display work as expected.

Step 9: Integration Testing: After implementing all the features, perform integration testing to ensure that the entire system works together as expected. Write tests that simulate user interactions with the system, such as registering, logging in, sending messages, creating groups, posting statuses, and going offline/online.

Step 10: Final Review and Refactoring: Review the entire codebase for any potential issues or improvements. Refactor the code as necessary to improve readability, efficiency, or adherence to best practices. Run all tests again to ensure that everything still works as expected after the refactoring.
step: Step 4: Messaging: Create a Message class with attributes such as sender, receiver, content, read receipt status, and encryption status. Implement methods to send and receive messages, update read receipt status, and encrypt/decrypt messages. Also, extend the Message class to support image sharing and emojis, GIFs, and stickers. After implementing these methods, write tests to ensure that messages can be successfully sent and received, that read receipts are updated correctly, and that encryption works as expected.

When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
